title: Impact Framework, Understand Work, and Growth at Scale
description: Bangaly Kaba, Director of Product Management at YouTube and former Head of Growth at Instagram, shares frameworks for choosing where to work, the critical concept of understand work, adjacent user theory for growth, and lessons from scaling platforms to billions of users. Covers career decisions, product leadership, team coaching, and storytelling.
summary: Bangaly discusses the impact framework (environment × skills) for career decisions, the Facebook understand-identify-execute methodology, how to do understand work to de-risk products, the adjacent user theory for growth, flywheels in multi-sided marketplaces, celebrity partnerships in Instagram's growth, the connections pivot that doubled retention, managing complex change, and using Bloom's Taxonomy for team coaching.

key_themes.description: Career impact determined by two factors: environment (manager, resources, scope, team, compensation, culture) and skills (communication, influence, strategy, execution)

key_themes.theme: Understand Work: Slow Down to Speed Up
key_themes.description: Intentional time to understand problems before executing prevents wasted effort. De-risks projects, increases win rate to 60-70%, creates velocity multiplier over time
Growth comes from users outside your current circle. Identify who's adjacent, become them, watch how they use product, understand what's missing for them
Multi-sided marketplaces need flywheels connecting all sides. Understand job-to-be-done and value at every interaction. Connect product to users' actual daily lives
Change requires: vision, skills, incentives, resources, action plan. Missing any creates confusion, resistance, anxiety, or false starts
Have 3-4 mentors (one per week), not one. Voracious reading, watching others work, learning frameworks from thought leaders builds product skill

key_themes.theme: Product Leadership as Coaching and Team Sport
key_themes.description: PM is a coach, not CEO. Build teams of role players, not just stars. Success measured by coaching tree - who did you develop to greater heights
Teaching classroom of 7-year-olds requires same skills as leading product teams: communication, vision, influence. People owe you nothing - must earn buy-in

key_insights.quote: The impact is only achievable by looking at two sets of variables, a set of variables related to the environment, a set of variables related to your skills, and really breaking down each and understanding what's happening in the environment bit by bit and what's happening with your skills and where are you hindered structurally within the environment?
key_insights.context: Explaining framework for choosing where to work and maximizing career impact
key_insights.insight: Career impact = environment × skills. Analyze each element separately. Environment includes: manager, resources, scope, team, compensation, culture

key_insights.quote: Compensation is a reflection of the input, the impact that you're having, and you're leveling how you are, how much scope you have is a derivative of how much impact you're driving. The more impact you're driving at your company, the more people feel like you can operate independently, you can drive real results the more that scope they'll give you.
key_insights.context: Discussing why impact should be the optimization target, not compensation
key_insights.insight: Optimize for impact first. Compensation and scope are derivatives of impact. More impact = more independence and scope

key_insights.quote: Your manager is the most important variable in the environment, because a great manager who is empathetic, who is aware of what's going on, who is a great communicator, has the ability to move the chess pieces around and to fix some of these for you either immediately or in time.
key_insights.context: Explaining why people leave jobs, not companies
key_insights.insight: Manager is the most important environment variable. A great manager can fix scope, resources, team issues. Poor manager = limited impact

key_insights.quote: First you have to really understand from first principles what is actually going on. So understand, identify, execute. You identify something, someone says, 'Hey, you know what? This would be great to build.' And you identify that, then you go pull data to go justify why that would be great to build... but it ultimately doesn't succeed.
key_insights.context: Contrasting bad pattern (identify, justify, execute) with good pattern (understand, identify, execute)
key_insights.insight: Avoid identify-justify-execute trap. Always start with understand work to avoid building wrong thing. De-risk before full execution

key_insights.quote: Understand work is an intentional affordance in your execution to do the work that helps you to de-risk a project and to learn what's going on. When I say an intentional affordance, meaning you put it down like Lenny is going to work on this thing. Lenny as a product manager is going to write a strategy.
key_insights.context: Defining what understand work actually is and how to operationalize it
key_insights.insight: Understand work must be scheduled and allocated like features. Put it on roadmaps. Don't assume it happens in background

key_insights.quote: We were doing 60% execution, 40% understand work. Right. And over time, as we understand more and more, the mix shifts. Now my teams are probably doing 80% execution, 20 to or 85% and 20 to 15% understand work.
key_insights.context: Showing how understand work ratio changes as product matures at YouTube
key_insights.insight: New teams need 40% understand work. As knowledge builds, shift to 80-85% execution. Balance changes with domain maturity

key_insights.quote: What is a better outcome? Is it a better outcome to just ship more faster now, but most of the things aren't unimpactful? Right. Or is it a better outcome to ship fewer things but really work on making sure that you're shipping them in the best way and de-risking a lot of other things so that a year later your win rate's higher and your velocity is higher?
key_insights.context: Contrasting fast shipping with high-quality, de-risked shipping
key_insights.insight: Counterintuitive: slow down to understand problems, increase win rate to 60-70%, compound velocity over time. Better than shipping more faster

key_insights.quote: When you're in a hypergrowth product, it's really, really important to understand who your users are today and the persona of the user, what motivates them, why they're using it, but then also to understand who is the next user? Who is the user who could be using this product, but for some reason it doesn't work for them, and understanding who that adjacent user is.
key_insights.context: Introducing the adjacent user concept critical to hypergrowth
key_insights.insight: Identify current users AND adjacent users (those who want to use product but don't). Growth comes from converting adjacent users

key_insights.quote: You have to use the product like them and see how it's working, what's broken with it. And so at an Instacart, the adjacent user, the original user might've been like an office admin who is going to buy this thing every week... But then the next adjacent user might've been the mom of three or four... who's home with the kids and they need to depend on Instacart, versus later on it might be they're a single person in New York who does this out of convenience.
key_insights.context: Showing how adjacent users have different needs and use cases than current users
key_insights.insight: Adjacent users have different jobs-to-be-done, optimization criteria, and contexts. Must deeply understand them, not just current users

key_insights.quote: It was our ability to think outside the box and understand that we needed to have a web presence because it was critical for international growth and it also helped with SEO. And so the idea of launching web really drove and actually increased Instagram's growth by 10% the minute we launched it.
key_insights.context: Explaining Instagram's web launch strategy and growth impact
key_insights.insight: Instagram web launch was critical for international growth and SEO. Celebrity-news-SEO flywheel magnified growth 10% immediately

key_insights.quote: We had to convince Kevin and Mikey that it was actually not the right thing to do to prioritize celebrities to everybody because we were basically biting bite your nose to spank your face... the regular person wasn't having a great experience. We had to get regular human-to-human connections in the first whatever, when people first sign up so that when you let me actually go make your first post, your friends would see it.
key_insights.context: Describing the connections pivot that required recommending friends over celebrities
key_insights.insight: The connections pivot doubled retention by prioritizing friend connections over celebrity follows. People need validation from friends first

key_insights.quote: We strive for this concept of what we call perceived simplicity, which is there are advanced features in the product and they are easily discoverable when you look for them, but they're effectively hidden if you're not looking for them. So I go and I sit in team meetings and see how they operate. I just listen.
key_insights.context: On learning from others and managing teams
key_insights.insight: Listen to teams first before giving input. Learn people by name and story. Build relationships before giving direction

key_insights.quote: One thing that I also think about a lot, and I don't know if this is just a me thing, but I think about PM as a team sport. Right. Leading product teams is really about being the coach and helping other people to see what their role is on the team and to maximize them. People talk a lot about product as you're the CEO, and I don't actually fully believe that analogy.
key_insights.context: Describing PM leadership philosophy as coaching
key_insights.insight: Think of PM leadership as coaching a team, not being a CEO. Not everyone needs to be a star - build strong role players

key_insights.quote: I have a good friend who's a college basketball coach, and he taught me about this idea of your coaching tree. You take a lot of pride in who are your assistants... and where do they go on to be head coaches? And what legacy do they have because you were able to instill a bit in them? I like to think about this as well, because I think it's really important for product leaders, think about what is their leadership tree.
key_insights.context: Discussing how great product leaders build others into leadership
key_insights.insight: Measure leadership success by your coaching tree - who did you develop? Legacy is about people you've helped grow, not just products shipped

key_insights.quote: People and teams don't really reach... They don't actually reach their goals. They fall to the level of their systems. And that to me was really powerful because I struggle a lot with just being balanced in life... But the problem is that I don't... My system for that specifically, I tend to... I'm not rigorous with it is when I need to be. But on the other hand, at work, I'm very rigorous in the systems and processes.
key_insights.context: Sharing a life motto about systems and achievement
key_insights.insight: People and teams fall to the level of their systems, not their goals. Build systems for what matters (health, work, relationships)
